newsitem.title: POLAND: POLAND SEES BANK PBK INVESTOR CHOSEN NEXT WEEK.
newsitem.headline: POLAND SEES BANK PBK INVESTOR CHOSEN NEXT WEEK.

text.p: Poland will likely choose an investor for 10 to 65 percent of Powszechny Bank Kredytowy SA (PBK) next week, the director of the economy ministry's restructuring and privatisation department said on Wednesday.

"Negotiations with investors are continuing and next week there'll be the final decision," Adam Kowalczyk told a news conference. The decision has already been postponed for several weeks, with June 12 the most recent target date missed.
A consortium of Polish Development Bank (PBR), Bank Przemyslowo-Handlowy (BPH), Kredyt Bank and insurer Warta has confirmed it was bidding for at least 51 percent of PBK.
Earlier this month the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) said it was willing to buy up to 15 percent of the bank.
Samsung Life Insurance, a subsidiary of South Korea's Samsung, has also expressed interest in buying a PBK stake.
HSBC Investment Services, the adviser on the privatisation, has estimated the bank as having a total value of between 1.2 billion and 1.6 billion zlotys.
A public offering of another 15 percent of PBK is due in October.
The bank lifted net profit last year to 212.9 million zlotys from from 121.1 million in 1995.
